page.title: 16Cockerham Parish Waterways
page.content: To the East of the Region runs The Kendal to Preston canal,a manmade waterway 41.5 miles long.It's minimum width is 42ft,minimum depth 6ft. and it is lined with puddled clay 1-3ft. thick.Meandering as it follows the contours of the land,there are no locks in this stretch,Built initially for freight traffic in 1797 by the Canal Company,taken over by the Land N.W.Rail Co.in 1864 and Nationalised by British Waterways in 1948,it is now used for recreational purposes.Small boats,pleasure cruisers and fisherman are regular users and the banks are a haven for wildlife.The other main waterway is the R.Cocker,a slow running river in times of low rainfall in the Summer,it has been severely affected by pollution killing off the few Sea Trout which venture up. Many Mallard duck & sometimes Swans breed.
